utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Katie Pavlich, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and Tom Shillue. It's 5 o'clock in New York City and this is “The Five.” Fox News alert. President Trump announcing a short time ago that Sarah Sanders is leaving the White House as press secretary. White House correspondent Kevin Corke joins us now with the very latest. Kevin, it was very touching for the president to bring her up on stage at the event and to give her a moment to say a few things. And for the American people. She will be living at the end of the month.

utterances.speaker: KEVIN CORKE, WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Yes. You are spot on. And by the way, she's just the third woman in history. You of course one of the other two, D.D. Myers of course back in 1993. And while we don't know exactly where the next chapter will lead, we can tell you it will likely take her back home to the razorback State of Arkansas.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: She's done an incredible job. We have been through a lot together, and she is tough but she's good. You know, you also have tough and bad, right? She's tough and she's good. She's great.

utterances.speaker: CORKE
utterances.utterance: Kind words by the president at that event that you just mentioned not long ago. You remember she assumed the role in July of 2017 after Sean Spicer left the job. She also stood in for Spicer during the dismissal of former FBI Director Jim Comey and the controversy following it. She did such a great job, the president said that's what he elevated her to that position. And now after two and a half years on the job, it's time for a new challenge.

utterances.speaker: SARAH HUCKABEE-SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: I'll try not to get emotional because I know crying can make us look weak sometimes, right? This has been the honor of a lifetime, the opportunity of a lifetime. I couldn't be prouder to have had the opportunity to serve my country and particularly to work for this president. He has accomplished so much in these two and half years. It's truly been something I will treasure forever.

utterances.speaker: CORKE
utterances.utterance: I can tell you this, I just got a text about 15 minutes ago from a White House official. She called Sanders a consummate professional, someone who loves her country, and all of its people including the people with whom she disagrees very strongly politically. The president also talking about this on Twitter, he said all the right things about someone he called a very talented person. Uniquely so, Sarah Sanders stepping down at months end. Dana, back to you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Kevin Corke, we thank you for that. We'll just spend a few minutes talking about this. Because this is a momentous thing when a press secretary leaves and a new one comes in. It has been a different role than in the past in the last little bit. But one thing you can say for sure, Jesse, she was one of the very trusted advisors of the president. So, in addition to doing press secretary role, she also is somebody that he used as a counselor.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: She was really in his inner circle, and it speaks to her talent and grace and compassion and intellect. She is going to be really missed because she was a real crusader for the Trump agenda. She's incredibly articulate, not afraid to go toe to toe with the press, who despised her who despise President Trump and those press conferences, we don't see them as much as we used too but they can be very, very entertaining and combative. And she always kept her composure --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think it's been like 94 days.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's been a while. But she's always kept her composure, and she was right on the money with what she said and I think we're going to miss her. But because she's got a young family. She wants to spend time with them and I think that's very important.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Juan, when I was a press secretary, I didn't even have to keep alive a plant. So, I never understood how she could be able to take care of three beautiful children at the same time.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: I think it's tremendously difficult. Talk about a time-consuming occupation. She's on call all the time. There's just no getting away especially 24/7 it looks like.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There's a lot that you don't see behind the scenes as well, like the logistical part of getting the press to and from where they need to be at the right time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I just think that, you know, the sad part is, I like Sarah Sanders. I was pained when I saw that comedian at the White House correspondents' dinner make fun of her while she was sitting there. I thought she handled it with some grace. But I got to say, I mean, I just think the whole relationship between the press and the Trump White House is broken. Jesse mentioned the absence of daily briefings. I just can't imagine. I've never seen a White House that doesn't have a daily briefing --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, they would argue that they -- Katie, they are more transparent because you get to hear directly from the president all the time, which is what they asked the press secretary about all the time, is what is the president think. Well, he tells you.

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes. And he'll walk out before he gets on his helicopter to go wherever he is going and speak with the press more often than a number of presidents have. But being in the room with Sarah Sanders when she was giving those briefings, it was hot and the room was packed. And she did it with grace and she did everything she good to get the press what they needed.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And to your point about the logistics, there is so much that goes on behind the scenes that I don't think the staff gets enough credit for in terms of getting --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And you do hear it from the reporters that for all the things that they need, the day-to-day. Like, check this, do that. That the press super responsive and, anyway. So, we wish her the very best. This is not the last you'll see of Sarah Sanders, indeed. Let's move on. President Trump also facing massive backlash after staying in an interview that he would be open to hearing dirt on his 2020 rivals from foreign governments. Watch.

utterances.speaker: GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS, CHIEF ANCHOR, ABC NEWS
utterances.utterance: Your campaign, time around, if foreigners, if Russia, China, if someone else offers you information on an opponent, should they accept it or should they call the FBI?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I think maybe you do both. I think you might want to listen. I don't -- there's nothing wrong with listening. If somebody called from a country, Norway, we have information on your opponent. I think I want to hear it.

utterances.speaker: STEPHANOPOULOS
utterances.utterance: You want that kind of interference in our elections?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: It's not an interference. They have information. I think I'd take it. If I thought there was something wrong, I'd go maybe to the FBI, if I thought there was something wrong. But when somebody comes up with oppo research, right, they come up with oppo research. Let's call the FBI? The FBI doesn't have enough agents to take care of it. But you go and talk honestly to congressmen, they all do it. They always have, and that's the way it is. It's called oppo research.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Democratic 2020 candidates quick to pounce as you can imagine. Joe Biden tweeting that "It's a threat to our national security." Kamala Harris taking it a step further, saying "the president himself is a national security threat." Kirsten Gillibrand saying "it's time for Congress to begin impeachment hearings," and Elizabeth Warren echoing Gillibrand, also calling for impeachment. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer harshly criticizing the president.

utterances.speaker: NANCY PELOSI, SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE
utterances.utterance: The president gave us once again evidence that he does not know right from wrong. It's a very sad thing. For the president to be so cavalier to disregard to be indifferent to law and any sense of ethics that who we are as a country to say he would invite foreign intervention, intelligence community, with great confidence has put forth that the Russians interfered in our election. It's an assault on our democracy.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER, D-N.Y., SENATE MINORITY LEADER
utterances.utterance: To say that it is OK to interfere, that we shouldn't have any law enforcement, that we should have no knowledge, is to encourage Russia, China, North Korea, Iran, to interfere in our elections with no recourse. Shame, shame.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, I was gone one day --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- and I get back and we're still talking about Russia. But this is obviously getting a lot of attention today.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This might be one of the dumbest controversies in the Trump administration and there's been a lot of dumb controversies. I think this might even take the cake. So little George goes into the Oval and he starts trying to create a scandal over a hypothetical. So, George comes in, Mr. President, the ambassador to China, you know, he says to you that Bernie stiffed a waitress at Denny's. What do you do? Trump says I would listen. Maybe I would call the FBI. Impeach! I mean, you have to be kidding me. Trump gets word that Bernie stiffed a waitress he has to call the FBI? There are thousand different hypothetical scenarios that you could be talking about. What did the president say? I'd listen. Maybe I would call the FBI. That's all he said. The left is freaking out over a hypothetical but they are not looking at the reality. Hillary actually did this. Hillary paid a foreign agent to get Russian dirt and then she used it to wiretap President Trump. Or what about warrants foreign interference? How about all those foreign governments paid millions of dollars to Clinton Foundation when she was running for president? Or little Adam Schiff. Remember he was on the phone call. We have the audio. We have naked Trump. He was all ears. He didn't call the FBI. The whole thing is so stupid and it goes back to the Trump tower meeting where Don Jr. thought he was going to get dirt on Hillary, didn't get it, they didn't have it. No money changed hands, like it did with the Clintons and the whole meeting was set up by Fusion GPS. This is all ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I'll tell you, Jesse. You a bigger show. Because as this parade goes on --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Can I borrow yours?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- you're going to have to keep shoveling to try to get out of this one. Let me just say.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is so ridiculous. There is a United States law. This is not a matter of opposition research. There is a law that says you cannot accept money or in-kind contributions from a foreign government.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, we are going to lock Hillary up?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, let me finish. This is -- this is a president who --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- was Nancy Pelosi said cannot tell right from wrong, but legal from illegal. And this is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Tell me about the dossier. How is it different than the dossier?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is totally different.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, how is it different?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is -- are you kidding? Fusion GPS is an American company. So not only --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Christopher Steele is a foreign agent.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Stop. Let me just --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And he got the dirt from Russians.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Enough of the shoveling. Let me just speak the truth.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, it's facts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Christopher Wray who is Trump's FBI director, he said this is wrong. What did Trump say? Christopher Wray is wrong. No, Christopher Wray, the FBI director, is right. And by the way, Jesse, when you try to blame and deride George Stephanopoulos, this was no got you moment. He is in the Oval Office.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He is doing this to every Republican since there was no collusion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. He is -- OK. The president is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Since you're not colluding, would you accept foreign dirt?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- sitting. The president is -- are you --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- essentially, you are insulting the president because the president knows exactly what he's doing --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- knows exactly what he's saying. This is no got you moment. You saw the sound bite.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, you have no answer on the dossier.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The dossier --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, this is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You have no answer.

utterances.speaker: WILLLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Fusion GPS is not an American company?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, where do they get it from?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Stop.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Russians.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Get out of here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Read the Mueller report.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Fusion GPS was working with Christopher Steele as an American --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You guys are running away from what happened today, aren't you?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- opposition research firm.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No. You are upset over Trump and you don't look at Hillary.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I will talk about what's happening today if you let me finish the sentence. So, the question is, does it apply to everybody, does the standard apply? So, during the 2016 election, apparently, it was OK to reach out with cash and money to pay foreign actors to get research from Russian adversarial sources to then bring it to the FBI. But Nancy Pelosi today is saying that if someone reaches out to you as a Republican, that is unethical. That is a criminal cover-up and that is not allowed. When it comes to the dossier, when the left was exposed as being behind the funding for that, the Clinton campaign and the DNC, they claimed it was just opposition research. It doesn't matter that it came from a foreign source or who the source was. We were doing our job as a campaign to get information. But when the president uses the same argument from the Oval Office saying he might call the FBI but he's going to listen to the information, then all of a sudden, they are calling for more impeachment on the basis that he's a criminal. Well, there's a double standard here. Do we want foreign interference in our elections? No. There are reasons why we have laws about foreign donations and foreign money being used for campaigns. But if are going to talk about this, there's going to be a whole lot of people in Washington, D.C., who were guilty of colluding or using information from foreign governments, including Democrats, to interfere in elections and legislation.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Tom hasn't had a chance to talk yet and it's 5.12. Go for it.

utterances.speaker: TOM SHILLUE, HOST
utterances.utterance: Democrats, just don't talk to Norway, OK? Because the president is going to take the call.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The (Inaudible) we did the press secretary today, it was like what did we do?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: But, yes, I agree. Jesse, you are totally dead on. It is completely ridiculous. The story is ridiculous. It was a fabricated story because George planted this -- you know, what would you do if this? I wish the president said well, I'm glad I didn't contact the FBI the last time around because the guy who was running the FBI was working against me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: So that's one example when you shouldn't call the FBI, when the head of the FBI is working for the other campaign, which is what happened.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Papadopoulos contacted the FBI's and said all these foreign agents are trying to spy on me. And what do they do to him?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just tell you. You guys are covering up for something that's inexcusable.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Remember, when they give you this information, they have hooks in you and you are not representing the best interests of our country. Either you're working for that foreign government or you're working --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, Hillary is working for Russia then.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? This is unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that was a missed opportunity on a couple of things. One, I've been so terrified of getting in trouble that I would always call the FBI. Because I do not ever want to get in trouble. And I know that if the Russians and Chinese or the Norwegians or the Swiss, if they called me with information, I would call. But I also think that President Trump could say well, what about the Obama administration? What were they doing to prevent interference in our election?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I would love to hear the answer to that, George, and flip it on him. And also, is another good example of doing a really important big interview to broaden out your reach and the interview, even though they talked about the economy a little bit, something like this is going to blow up. So, it's like, if you were the press secretary, you want to jump on that grenade. Here we are once again. We got to move on. Bernie Sanders says when it comes to taxes, we'd all be delighted to pay more. Can you believe that? That's next.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Bernie Sanders still trying to convince everyone that socialism is good for America. In a recent interview, he goes on to compare the United States to socialist ideologies in Europe. But when it comes to paying for it all, listen to this.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.utterance: As you know, the taxes and many of those countries are much higher than they are, the individual personal taxes are much higher than they are in the United States.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, I-VT, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Yes. But I suspect that a lot of people in this country would be delighted to pay more in taxes if they had health -- if they had a comprehensive health care as a human right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Delighted. Twenty-twenty presidential candidate John Hickenlooper urging his fellow Democrats to denounce socialism or risk another four years of President Trump.

utterances.speaker: FMR. GOV. JOHN HICKENLOOPER, D-COLO., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Democrats must say loudly and clearly that we are not socialist. If we do not, we will end up helping to reelect the worst president in this country's history.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, Jesse, it seems like some members of the media are catching onto this idea that this won't be paid for just by the rich but by everybody.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It took them long enough. I mean, they are not good at math, usually, the press. And it doesn't take a genius to realize you can raise taxes on every single American and you still can't pay for all of Bernie's schemes. Medicare for all, free housing, free college, Green New Deal. It's like $150 trillion. The budget alone for a year is about 4.5 trillion. It just doesn't add up. Bernie is not great at math, but that's fine. No one cares. We need Bernie to get the nomination. A Trump-Bernie match up, America deserves it. We've been good. We've been eating our vegetables.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: What? It's like punishment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We want -- and you know why it's a clear contrast. Socialism versus capitalism, America, Venezuela, control, freedom. We need it. And Bernie's poll numbers are rising. He has grassroots support in New Hampshire and Iowa.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He can win those first two.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I have to say I haven't seen these polls.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No, his numbers are going down.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Bernie's numbers are on the creeping up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm glad to say it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, no, they're creeping up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, Elizabeth Warren's are up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Warren's and Bernie's are up. Biden's are the one that are going down.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No, Bernie is losing a little bit of steam.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You think Bernie is losing steam?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, that's what polling shows.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Burned out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow. All right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: He's losing a little steam. Elizabeth Warren is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Guys, I'm trying to help Bernie though.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- gaining --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You want him the ultimate bad guy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Bernie is doing great.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You have Governor Hickenlooper trying to make the definition between Democrats and Democratic socialism and the full-blown socialism that Bernie Sanders is promoting. So, what's the difference between a socialist and a Democrat today?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think Democratic socialism is all about the social safety net in a country that is experiencing high levels of income inequality.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, what does that mean? Is that like how we're seeing with everything?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, no, no. Yes, because what you heard --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Everything is all right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think that Bernie gave a speech at George Washington University. Today is Thursday to it must have been Tuesday. In which he laid it out, Katie. He said, you know, you want universal coverage for health care, you want health care. You want to make sure that young people are able to go to college without leaving with unbearable debt. You want to make sure that housing isn't punishing for working people, that they can afford a place to live. And he went on in this way. But I just want to speak to your point, Katie, about taxes. Because we have polls here at Fox News and we had a poll in January, 70 percent of the people we polled said yes, raise taxes especially on people who make over $10 million a year. Raise 65 percent. Raise taxes on people making more than a million. And when it comes to wealth, and wealth is, you know, not just earned income but income that you have sitting and growing exponentially because it's in the markets. Guess what? Sixty percent of the millionaire said we should be paying more taxes. So, this is not some crazy idea. Most Americans think yes, the rich should pay more.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, they can write a check to the treasury at any point in time if they would like to voluntarily pay more in taxes. But Dana, healthcare is a big issue. And people don't like the system now under Obamacare. Bernie Sanders is at least talking about it but there is the difference between healthcare and health insurance, right, and being able to receive medical care?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. The Medicare for all question, you can get a fairly high number when you ask a group of people but when you asked the second question and the third question, it drops just precipitously. it doesn't work for them.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: One of the things Bernie Sanders has been saying is that we need to, we, as a Democratic socialist, need to explain to older voters what we mean by socialist or socialism. And I think that he realizes because it pulls terribly, especially with reliable senior citizens who are voters or baby boomers or even the silent generation and part of generation x who says, no, obviously, that's a failed system. It has failed all around the world. But I think what they really want is not socialism and that the government is running the industries and deciding things. What they really want is a much larger welfare state. They might have to find a different word to explain what that means because welfare -- larger welfare state probably is going to sell either. But their argument is that if people think that they have their health care taken care of and they are not going to be buried in college education debt, then that -- then it'll be fine. The thing that conservatives have to think about is that people are becoming much more willing to think that the government can solve these problems for them.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And that is on the rise. The Trump administration, and going into this election, they've also framed it at the State of the Union. Capitalism versus socialism as Jesse said.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But going forward and for the long-range health of the movement and the party, for the Republican Party, being able to explain the government is not going to be able to solve this for you is really key.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, Tom, what about --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, socialist safety net doesn't work for you?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Tom, what about all those kids who just want socialism? All the kiddos --

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: They don't understand it. And they get as polls. And I am sure, Juan, that you are right about this poll. They ask people would you like this to happen and would you be willing to pay more taxes? Yes, I would. But when you run against them, they're going to lose. When people who say I'm going to raise your taxes. Lose. And then if the Democrat says I'm going to raise your taxes, they are going to lose this time. And Hickenlooper is right. And last week when he said don't say socialism, he got booed in front of a bunch of Democrats.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. All right. New cringeworthy moments coming from the campaigns of top 2020 Democrats. That's up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We've seen it before but now Democrats are taking their head scratching campaign moments to a whole new level. Of course, remember this gem from Elizabeth Warren.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, D-MASS., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Hold on a sec. I'm going to get me a beer. My husband Bruce is now here. Do you want a beer?

utterances.speaker: BRUCE MANN, ELIZABETH WARREN'S HUSBAND
utterances.utterance: No. I pass on the beer for now.

utterances.speaker: WARREN
utterances.utterance: I will sit down.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, Warren's campaign pushing the alcohol infused strategy a little further, offering supporters to drink with her if they donate her presidential campaign which then enters them into a contest. Shillue, I think you should pony up a few dollars just so you might give a shot to drink the Mule.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I wouldn't want to hang -- look, her husband doesn't want to drink with her.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She needs a drinking buddy. I'll do it. You're the best buddy to drink with. That's your reputation at least.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Doesn't look too comfortable. Look at the --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's like --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It looks like she hasn't drank a beer before.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's like a bottle.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She's not using two hands.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That wasn't -- Dana, what is the -- there has to be some sort of fund-raising strategy here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think it's this. I think people want -- we've talk about authenticity and people want experiences.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And people -- like we all have enough stuff. So, I think that this -- if you want to raise money and get some buzz going for your campaign, it's probably a good idea.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Get some buzz, I like that Dana.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me answer your question to Dana. The strategy is that you want lots of people to contribute, it's not the money, it's not the $5--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: More donors.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's that you want several donors. You want thousands of people. And guess what, this is a strategy, Jesse that was engineered by President Obama. He did it. President Trump offered dinner at Mara Largo.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He's also offered dinner in DC and it in in New York at Trump Tower. So - and his kids would come, his wife would come, so I think that's--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Kim Kardashian would be there?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Kim Kardashian - today - if you showed up today, Dana, you would have got--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But I think, Katie, the reason this is interesting is because she just looks a little awkward with the beer.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No, this recent spats of Democrats doing things like this, were - they were doing it because Beto was doing it first.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's a good point.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So Beto was the one who was getting his teeth done at the dentist and doing all the weird stuff with his haircut. And then all these other Democrats were like, "Oh My God, Beto's getting all this attention. He raised all of that money. We have to do the same thing. Kirsten Gillibrand was lifting the weights - remember that? Here, Elizabeth Warren grabbing the beer. So generally speaking, this has been done before. But this one section of time was chasing Beto.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Spat?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Spat.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No spate.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Spate?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Spate.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Spate.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Up next, we have Joe Biden who conveniently forgets some of the time in the White House when he was Obama's VP. Watch.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Know what I was most proud of? For eight years, there wasn't one single hint of a scandal or a lie.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Will the media fact check this? I doubt that, Shillue?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I doubt it. What do we got? Fast and furious, IRS, Benghazi, spying on Trump - did they include spying on Trump?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't think they categorize as a scandal yet.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Spying on the media.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Spying on the media.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's going at the top of my list, and there's some others in there too. But yes there were funny.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, the Bergdahl trade, remember that one?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Big one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, but do you remember Eric Holder was the - what was - what did he call himself?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Wingman.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The Wingman.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Wingman--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All the Democrats say this. Michelle Obama has said it out on the campaign - well, the campaign trail, but also during her book tour, President Obama has said this in speeches. They are going to keep saying it. And even if the media does fact check them, I guarantee they're going to keep saying it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Pretty disgraceful. They keep saying it, these people were killed.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Who does that remind you of, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I just think it's the truth. But I think that the bigger truth is--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, stop.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The bigger truth is - Kellyanne Conway - I wonder what the government is saying about her service, maybe she should leave? How about Ryan Zinke using his office support? But how about Scott Pruitt - Oh, taxpayer-funded traveler.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, I don't think Trump is denying that his administration was scandal free.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's just funny that after eight years Biden is saying.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying to you, I just think if you want to go on about things like Benghazi, IRS, these are like pimples and you ignore a moat in your eye.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But no collusion, no obstruction. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I don't think that four dead Americans in Benghazi are pimples.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh what happened in Niger? Oh, I see.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: But - yes, I think that Democrats are a little bit disrespectful when they try to downplay no scandals, considering a number of the scandals in the Obama administration got people killed and they're still working on it. The IRS scandal ruined people's lives, so I know it's funny to joke about it - and they're obviously going to keep saying it, but there were serious life or death consequences to a lot of what the Obama administration did. And they can say all they want, but it's not true. But it is. And the families were affected or still feeling it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That is true. All right. Rounding out the cringe-worthy moments is Cory Booker. No one can forget this.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CORY BOOKER, D-N.J., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I'm going to release the e- mail about racial profiling, and I understand that that - the penalty comes with potential ousting from the Senate. And if Senator Cornyn believes that I violated Senate rules, I openly invite and accept the consequences. This is about the closest I'll probably ever have in my life to an "I am Spartacus moment".

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, now he's pulling back from his big moment and saying this.

utterances.speaker: BOOKER
utterances.utterance: I wasn't talking about myself. I was talking about Dick Durbin. I was like, Oh My God, I literally just have with a senior Senator in Illinois saying that if I'm going to get kicked out of the Senate, he wants to go too. And I'm like - basically that was the closest I'll ever come to seeing and I am Spartacus moment. But, again, we live in this echo chamber that people will try to take out something you say - so I'm six years in the Senate you can barely find moments where I popped up above the radar screen, because I was going to work people on other side of the isle.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't get it, Dick Durbin, Spartacus?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I think he was thinking about a different time he used the Spartacus reference, because he was clearly talking about himself, we just showed it in the video, he was not talking about Dick Durbin. But you know- -

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that he does have a point in that he did this moment - the Spartacus one and it's good - that's your - sometimes you only get one chance like and that's the brand. But he really hadn't done too much before it. The other - but there was a very partisan moment. Remember, he was the first person - Senator to testify against one of his own colleagues and that was Senator Jeff Sessions when he was becoming Attorney General.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He looks like he's losing weight then you, Jesse. I don't know. Anyway--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Looks good to me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't how to judge this, because I thought that he was referring to himself as Spartacus. I mean, maybe it's - he trying to spin. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think I'd own it. I'd maybe take the shirt off and get a little - get the sword.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Dick Durbin maybe like, "No man that was all you".

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I don't need it, just go for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. All right. South Carolina mom in legal trouble after confronting her son's bullies, up next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A South Carolina mom arrested last month after allegedly entering her child's school without permission. She confronted a group of children - children she says, they were bullying her son. The mom Jamie Louise Rathburn said this about why she got involved.

utterances.speaker: JAMIE LOUISE RATHBURN, MOTHER OF CHILD BULLIED IN SCHOOL
utterances.utterance: He got hit, kicked, hit with the computer. He was shoved. He was jerked off the slide from behind. I feel like my son was neglected. What I took as an OK, it wasn't. It was not OK. Mom shouldn't have done that. But I was upset and you see what happened when I allowed my emotions to control my behavior, I did something stupid and it got me arrested.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The school saying, they "Don't tolerate bullying regardless of age, but that it's never OK to confront other people's children". Meanwhile, the Wisconsin City considering putting an anti-bullying ordinance in place it fines parents if their children bully others. Now, Jesse, I just think that in this situation bullying can be dangerous. It can lead people to suicide and all the rest. But on the other hand isn't dealing with bullies a life experience, an opportunity to learn something?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, it depends the level of bullying. There's ridicule and then there's a certain natural level of bullying that takes place in middle school. But once it becomes, as she noted, violent or you're grabbing some kid off of a slide and its relentless and constant, you have to take action. She let the emotion get the best of her. She shouldn't have gone in to the school to confront the kids. Maybe do it outside the school. Maybe talk to the kids parents, maybe set up a parent-teacher conference or go talk to the administration. But it's a problem and the school sounded soft, like they weren't doing enough about it. So that - she shouldn't have gone to the school, but I'm glad now they're going to take steps.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But Dana, in fact, the school system says that they were watching the kid, they were where aware of this situation.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I just think this is human nature. It's - mothers want to protect their children. And I think - I know obviously fathers do too. But if you if you feel like the school isn't doing enough and you're a mom, and you are aching, because you - yes, it takes time to teach people how to deal with bullying and that's part of growing up. But if it gets to the point where she would thought her child was in danger, then there's not lot like you can do to stop a mom from protecting her children.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What would you do?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Well, my message to parents, the school is doing nothing. Your school is doing - schools don't do anything. They can't do anything. They cannot discipline students anymore, it's not being done. So something has to be done. In the old days, of course, my mother used to say, go punch him. So we used to fight it out, apparently you can't do that anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We can't do that.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: This thing about the school saying, it is never OK for a parent to approach another person's child, you could have told me that a long time ago. But watch me on the playground, that's all I do. I'm like, you knock it off, you I'm going to take that away from you right now. I mean, all I do is berate other people's children.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You're like a Americas dad.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Maybe more of America's dads are--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Katie, did you ever punch anybody up?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No. But when I was in high school a bunch of girls made their own gang against me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In high school?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And I survived.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And how you like her now?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It worked out OK. But you know what, I think that these zero- tolerance policies that schools have implemented have actually emboldened and - bullies, because what they do is, if you fight back as a kid who's getting bullied, you are suspended at the same rate as the bully. And if you're a friend who jumps in to defend someone who's being bullied, you are also punished and expelled or suspended from school. And the bullies don't care right about their behavior. And so you're punishing everybody equal instead of actually thinking about - punish that - for the bully.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So you are saying the anti-bullying ordinance in Wisconsin is counterproductive?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I don't know its typically about that one. But generally speaking around the country they've implemented these zero-tolerance policies for bullying and it's just like checking a box kind of thing, rather than looking at the situation and thinking who started it, why is this person bullying? Did this person respond in self-defense and that's, OK because that's the only way to really handle it. But they do treat it as like an equal playing field for the bully and the bullied, which I think only emboldens the bullies.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I think Tom is onto something. I mean, I think that if you punch out somebody saying, "Hey, you better stop it jerk".

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, you should do that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That works. But--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We don't encourage that here on “The Five,” though.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no. I'm talking about the school yard. All right. A new report says, meatless meat is the future – “The Five,” we're going to do a blind taste test next. You got to stay around for the fun.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: If you are a meat-eater you might want to stock up. A new report is now - is saying that most meat in 2040 won't come from animals. Instead, experts are predicting that 60% of it will be plant-based products made to resemble and taste like meat or be grown in vats. So what will it taste like? We're going to do a blind taste test. Traditional meat burgers versus a meatless burger in a moment, but first I want everyone's reaction. What is your first reaction just at looking at this, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't want to say, I don't want to ruin it. But just know what's what. I'm just not going to say. I just have a feeling.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: It's going to be a taste test. Would - do you think you could--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know what, you should do? You should actually blindfold me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So I'm not looking at it. I'm just tasting it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You can see the top on “The Five.”

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm going to close my eyes.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: The thing is--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: --and then you can hand me two.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. OK. Right now. Somebody is closing his eyes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm going to close my eyes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. Wait. Hold on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And you just hand me two in my hands.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I don't know - care if Jesse gets it right or wrong.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did you hand it the right way, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. This is the much better thing. And he's not cheating, I'm watching him. And he's like OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That one--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, my--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is so much better.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I like this one better.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: OK. So Jesse likes that one, we'll find out what - but, Katie, would you - do you want to eat meatless meat?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No, that's like really terrifying. It's going to turn us all the zombies, no offense.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm from a cattle ranching family, so I going to say, eat meat. But I'm also OK with if we need--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I don't want to go into that. Like if it's plant-based totally fine. But I don't want meat grown in the vat, that's weird.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Well, plant-based - the regular old veggie burgers, though, unless they do some hocus-pocus.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know what's better.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This one the blue plate - I think the blue plates are the real burger.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I think that's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But you think that's better. But you said this was better when you did the test.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I just had a funny aftertaste. That's why I changed my opinion.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I think right now - look, I didn't even taste the other one, but this doesn't taste right to me. I'd taste baked, I don't like it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Green--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I was right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This reminded me of a Charles Krauthammer wrote in May 7th of 2015 that, "I've long thought it will be our treatment of animals that our great-grandchildren will say, I can't believe they did that". And he thinks that this - he predicted this back in 2015.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, do they mistreat cows?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No they don't, that's not at all.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They slaughter them Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, obviously. But do they treat them - actually before they slaughter them?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But we're humans. Humans are meant to eat meat.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: There's nothing wrong with eating cows people. It's fine. Eat cows.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Eat meat and have one of these as your side dish.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think if you're Hindu, you'll eat cow.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Juan, it sounds like you are a meat guy. You don't even like the idea of this vegetarian meal?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean I - the funny thing is - I mean people, because I don't - I try not to eat red meat. People say here's a turkey burger, here's a veggie burger. They doesn't taste right to me, so I just don't eat.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You want to try this one then?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't want to eat it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He doesn't want to try it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't, because I don't eat it. But I'm just saying, it seems to me that - I think, there was a report this week from the Health somebody saying, "If you eat red meat, you have higher levels of cholesterol, blood pressure, more likely a heart attack".

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, Dumbo. If you eat red meat you're going to be strong.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: If you eat red meat, you're a good American.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You and I are the only ones that tried it.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes. And I - I didn't even try the real burger. But--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan and the women didn't even taste it.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: --to me, something little funny about that - something little funny about that. I don't like it.
